newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: COARSE WOOLS MAKE COMEBACK AT CHRISTCHURCH SALE.
newsitem.headline: COARSE WOOLS MAKE COMEBACK AT CHRISTCHURCH SALE.

text.p: Prices for coarse wool made a small comeback in Thursday's Christchurch sale after being left in the dust by finer wools at the season's first sales two weeks ago.
Wools of New Zealand said the strong market segment indicator jumped nine cents to 408 NZ cents/kg clean, while the fine segment indicator dropped 10 to 1,068 cents.
At the Christchurch and Napier sales on July 31, the fine wool indicator jumped 101 cents to 1078, while the strong segment indicator managed only a 12 cents gain to 399.
Wools of NZ said the overall market indicator closed up five cents on Thursday, at 484, while the medium segment indicator fell one cent to 622.
Compared with the Christchurch sale on July 31, merino fleece prices 18 and 19 micron were three to five percent dearer, 20 to 22 micron were unchanged and 23 micron were 1.5 percent cheaper.
Halfbred fleece 26 and 28 micron were one percent cheaper, while 29 to 33 micron were one percent dearer.

Crossbred fleece 32 micron were two percent dearer, 33 and 34 micron were up to one percent cheaper, 35 micron was four percent cheaper, 37 micron was one percent dearer and 38 micron super/good style longer wools were 2.5 percent dearer.
The offering of 2,175 tonnes included 37 percent crossbred fleece, 20 percent halfbred fleece, four percent merino fleece and 12 percent bulky skirtings.
Passings which failed to meet growers' price reserves amounted to 24 percent.
New Zealand exporters reported their major enquiry came from China and Europe, with support from local mills, India, Pakistan and Nepal.
The next sales are at Christchurch and Napier on August 21.
